questions.text: You are working on a research project and need to determine the appropriate usage of the Chi-square test. Which of the following sets of data would be most appropriate for utilizing the Chi-square test? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sex and type of cancer

 

  • The chi-square test is a nonparametric statistical method used to evaluate the significance of an association between two categorical variables.
  • Within the provided choices, the only pair of categorical variables (qualitative data) is sex and type of cancer. Therefore, this is the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Malignant melanoma
Rosai Dorfman disease

questions.text: A woman who had undergone total knee replacement surgery comes with complaints of knee pain with the loosening of implants. The following histopathological slide was obtained which showed foreign body giant cells along with the appearance highlighted in the image below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metallosis

 

The given clinical scenario and image with the said foreign body giant cell point towards a diagnosis of metallosis.

 

Metallosis is an uncommon complication following total joint replacements of high wear joints like hip and knees. It occurs when metallic components in medical implants, specifically joint replacements, abrade against one another. The metal from the prosthesis infiltrates the bone and soft tissue surrounding it resulting in pain or squeaking on weight bearing or loosening of implant. Sometimes it may be asymptomatic with imaging findings (cloud sign or bubble sign). Aspiration reveals dark fluid consisting of metallic debris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ochronosis: Ochronosis is a metabolic disorder characterized by the deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues, leading to pigmentation and arthritis. It is not associated with metallic debris or foreign body giant cells.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that would present with different histological findings, such as atypical melanocytes. It does not involve foreign body giant cells or metallic debris.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman disease: This is a rare disorder characterized by massive lymphadenopathy and histiocytosis with distinctive histological features, including the presence of histiocytes that exhibit emperipolesis. It does not involve metallic particles or joint replacements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metallosis is a rare complication of joint replacement surgeries, characterized by the release of metallic debris from implants, leading to a foreign body reaction with the formation of foreign body giant cells and potential loosening of the implant.

questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T9

 

The provided image shows a cross-sectional anatomy where key structures such as the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs are visible. At the T9 vertebral level, the liver and stomach are seen prominently, with the heart also visible, indicating that the section is at the level where these thoracic and upper abdominal structures overlap. The presence of the lungs further supports that this is a thoracic level.

 

 

 

Cross sectional anatomy of ABDOMEN:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T10: While the T10 level also shows some of the same structures, the visibility and position of the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs in this image are more indicative of T9.

 

Option C. T11: At the T11 level, the kidneys start to become visible, and the heart is usually not as prominent as it is at the T9 level.

 

Option D. T12: The T12 level typically shows the kidneys more clearly and does not include as much of the heart and upper liver as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.

questions.text: EEG pattern given below is suggestive of which of the following diseases? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Creutzfeldt- Jakob Disease

 

Periodic sharp wave complexes occurring every 1 second is usually seen in sporadic CJD.

 

Spongiform encephalopathy characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism.

 

**Startle myoclonus is very peculiar feature observed in CJD.

 

Signs on MRI:

 

  • Sporadic CJD: 80-90% - Cortical-Ribbon sign on MRI.
  • Variant CJD: Hockey-stick appearance on MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic encephalopathies show triphasic wave (Negative-positive-negative waves).

 

Option B. GTCS shows high voltage, spike wave discharges in all leads.

 

Option D. HSV show periodic lateralized epileptiform discharge (PLED) arising from temporal lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is associated with distinct EEG findings that are crucial for its diagnosis. Understanding the typical EEG patterns along with clinical presentation and advanced imaging can aid in the early and accurate diagnosis of this rapidly progressive and fatal disease.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology/Dementia/chap 438/12420

questions.text: A young child with absent thymus is brought to the OPD with features of hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

The patient most certainly has DiGeorge syndrome based on the clinical history and the imaging, which displays pharyngeal pouches (thymic and parathyroid defects). It might be brought on by faulty third- and fourth-pharyngeal-pocket development. The thymus' absence is expressly stated in the provided stem. Hence, choice 12 is the better of the two.

 

  • DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy that is caused by hemizygous interstitial deletion of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects, including conotruncal defects, hypoparathyroidism, and dysmorphic syndrome. Microdeletion at chromosome 22q11 can lead to variable presentations including -
  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia leading to T-cell deficiency
  • Cardiac defects
  • Hypocalcemia 2° to parathyroid aplasia.

          (Mnemonic: CATCH-22)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9 : External Auditory Meatus. The first pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the middle ear cavity, eustachian tube, and external auditory meatus. These structures are primarily involved in auditory functions and do not relate to the endocrine or immune system anomalies seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option B. 10: Palatine Tonsil. The second pharyngeal pouch develops into the palatine tonsils. While DiGeorge syndrome can include a range of pharyngeal derivatives issues, the palatine tonsil is not typically affected in ways that lead to the major clinical symptoms of thymus and parathyroid gland absence.

 

Option D. 14: Ultimobranchial Body. This derivative of the fourth pharyngeal pouch contributes to the development of the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid, which are responsible for calcitonin production. Although related to calcium metabolism, its involvement is distinct from the parathyroid gland's role in calcium homeostasis and does not directly relate to the primary symptoms of DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The most relevant site of defect in DiGeorge syndrome, given the symptoms described (absent thymus, hypoparathyroidism, and tetany), is associated with abnormalities in the third pharyngeal pouch—specifically the development of the inferior parathyroid glands and the thymus

questions.text: Identify the structure which is responsible for elevation and is supplied by the nerve emergency from the structure shown in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Risorius

 

Explanation:

 

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve, resulting in the marked elevation. The image depicts the floor of the fourth ventricle, as well as the facial colliculus.

 

 

The facial colliculus is a raised area on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brainstem, and it is associated with the motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The facial nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, including the risorius muscle, which is one of the muscles that can cause elevation of the corner of the mouth in smiling. Therefore, the structure that is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation would be the risorius muscle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral rectus: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

 

Option B. Superior oblique: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). This muscle is responsible for raising the upper eyelid (levator means "elevator"), allowing you to open your eyes.

 

The oculomotor nerve also innervates several other muscles that control eye movement and pupil constriction, making it an important cranial nerve for eye function

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risorius muscle, responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth laterally and aiding in expressions like smiling, is innervated by the facial nerve.

choices.text: 1 and 4 only

questions.text:
A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. Large frontal and parietal eminence
  2. Heavy cheek bones
  3. Smooth glabella
  4. Square orbits
  5. Narrow mastoid
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 3 and 5   

 

Female Skull Characteristics:

 

1. Large frontal and parietal eminence: These are more prominent in females.

 

3. Smooth glabella: Females typically have a smoother glabella compared to males.

 

5. Narrow mastoid: Female mastoid processes are generally narrower and less prominent.

 

These characteristics help in identifying the skull as female.

 

Note - General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are

 

  • Size: Male bones are larger than female bones.
  • Roughness: Male bones are more rougher due to increased muscle attachment areas. Females have smooth features
  • Weight: Male bones are heavier than female bones
  • Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.
  • Square features: Male have square features, whereas females have rounded features

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

 

Other Options

 

2. Heavy cheek bones: Typical in males, as a general rule, female bones are lighter than male bones.

 

4. Square orbits: Males have squarish features, whereas females have roundish features.

 

Educational objective

 

Most features are larger, rougher, and more prominent in male skull, except frontal eminence, parietal eminence and orbits which are more prominent or larger in females

questions.text: Gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GABRA-1

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), also known as Janz syndrome, is a common type of generalized epilepsy that typically manifests in adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and absence seizures. A mutation in the GABRA-1 gene, which encodes for the alpha-1 subunit of the GABA(A) receptor, has been linked to juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The GABA(A) receptor is crucial in mediating inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain, and mutations in this gene can disrupt normal neuronal function, leading to the seizures characteristic of JME.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHYNN-1: This gene is not associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The correct genes associated with JME include GABRA-1 and others like CLNC2, EFHC1, and CACNB4.

 

Option C. FMR-1: The FMR-1 gene is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which is a leading cause of inherited intellectual disability, not juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because not all the genes listed are involved in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Only GABRA-1 from the options given is directly linked to JME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The GABRA-1 gene is a key genetic factor in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the green muscles marked? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Depression

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in green is the lateral pterygoid muscle, and its primary function among the given options is depression of the mandible (opening the mouth). "Depression is brought about mainly by the lateral pterygoid" and it is "indispensible for actively opening the mouth."

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  • Depression of the mandible (primary active opener of the mouth)
  • Protrusion of the mandible
  • When one side contracts, it turns the chin to the opposite side

 

While the digastric, geniohyoid, and mylohyoid muscles assist in depression, they primarily help when the mouth is opened wide or against resistance. The lateral pterygoid is the main muscle responsible for actively opening the mouth during normal function.
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protrusion:

 

  • Protrusion refers to the forward movement of the lower jaw (mandible).
  • The lateral along with medial pterygoid muscle are responsible for protruding the mandible. When this muscle contracts on both sides, it causes the jaw to move forward.

 

Option B. Elevation:

 

  • Elevation refers to the upward movement of the mandible, closing the mouth.
  • The primary muscles responsible for jaw elevation are the masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid muscles. The lateral pterygoid's main function is not jaw elevation but rather protrusion.

 

Option D. Retraction:

 

  • Retraction refers to the backward movement of the mandible.
  • The primary muscles involved in jaw retraction are the temporalis and the posterior fibers of the digastric muscle. The lateral pterygoid is not primarily responsible for this movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: Match the given cellular components with their respective marker enzymes.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C

 

The correctly matched answer is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C.

 

Each organelle has specific enzymes that act as marker enzymes, which are used to identify them after centrifugation in laboratory settings.

 

  • Mitochondria: ATP synthase (D) is a key enzyme of mitochondria involved in the production of ATP during oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Peroxisomes: Catalase (A) is the enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) into water and oxygen, a primary function of peroxisomes.
  • Golgi complex: Galactosyl transferase (B) is associated with the Golgi complex and is involved in glycosylation, the process of adding sugar residues to proteins and lipids.
  • Endoplasmic reticulum: Glucose-6-phosphatase (C) is an enzyme located in the endoplasmic reticulum, crucial for glucose homeostasis and the final step in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misplaces the enzymes, associating ATP synthase with the wrong organelle (ER), and Catalase with Golgi instead of peroxisomes.

 

Option C. Incorrect pairing of glucose-6-phosphatase with mitochondria and galactosyl transferase with peroxisomes.

 

Option D. Incorrectly matches enzymes, such as pairing ATP synthase with the ER and glucose-6-phosphatase with peroxisomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each cellular organelle can be identified by its specific marker enzyme. Knowing these associations is essential for understanding cell biology and organelle function.

questions.text: Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arm span

 

The image shows the measurement of a child's height using a stadiometer. The alternative method that can be used for measuring height is arm span. The arm span is a measurement from the tip of one middle finger to the tip of the other middle finger when the arms are outstretched horizontally. This measurement is typically close to the child's height and can be used as an alternative method, especially in cases where the child is unable to stand properly.

 

The proportion of arm span to height changes with age but is generally close to the height measurement. In clinical practice, when direct measurement of height is not feasible, arm span can be a reliable surrogate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head circumference: Head circumference is measured using a measuring tape and is an important metric in assessing brain growth and development, especially in infants and young children, but it is not an alternative for height measurement.

 

Option C. Crown-rump length: Crown-rump length is a measurement used during an ultrasound in early pregnancy to estimate the gestational age of the fetus, not a method for height measurement in children.

 

Option D. Knee height: Knee height is not typically used for measuring height in children and is more often used in adults, particularly the elderly, to estimate height when they are unable to stand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arm span can be used as an alternative method for measuring height, especially when direct height measurement is not feasible.

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

 

The Nile blue test is a laboratory test used to assess fetal lung maturity by staining desquamated fetal cells obtained from amniotic fluid. The correct interpretation of this test is that if more than 50% of the cells stain orange, it indicates pulmonary maturity. Therefore, the presence of more than 50% blue cells, as mentioned in Option D, suggests immature lungs rather than maturity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio > 2.0: The Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio is a well-established method for assessing fetal lung maturity. A ratio greater than 2.0 typically indicates mature fetal lungs.

 

Option B. Positive shake test: The shake test, also known as the foam stability test, assesses the presence of surfactant in amniotic fluid. A positive shake test, indicated by the formation of stable bubbles, suggests fetal lung maturity.

 

Option C. Increased phosphatidyl glycerol: The presence of phosphatidylglycerol in amniotic fluid is another indicator of lung maturity, particularly in pregnancies complicated by diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:


The presence of more than 50% orange cells in the Nile blue test indicates fetal lung maturity, whereas more than 50% blue cells suggest immaturity.

questions.text: Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-C

 

Explanation:

 

  • MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser): This syndrome has a karyotype of 46XX.
  • Swyer Syndrome: This condition is characterized by 46XY karyotype.
  • Turner Syndrome: This is due to monosomy X, having a karyotype of 45XO.
  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: This condition occurs in individuals with a karyotype of 46XY, where there is a complete androgen insensitivity, resulting in a phenotypically female appearance despite having male (XY) chromosomes.

 

Matching:

 

  1. MRKH: 46XX
  2. Swyer Syndrome: 46XY
  3. Turner Syndrome: 45XO
  4. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the karyotypes associated with different syndromes helps in diagnosing and managing these conditions effectively. MRKH is associated with 46XX, Swyer syndrome with 46XY, Turner syndrome with 45XO, and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome with 46XY.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 446,447

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with low free T4. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

 

HYPOTHYROIDISM

 

Types:

 

  1. Primary Hypothyroidism - Increased TSH with low T4 levels.
  2. Secondary hypothyroidism - TSH can be low, normal or elevated slightly. The latter is due to secretion of immune-active but bio-active forms of TSH. Confirmation of diagnosis is done by detecting low levels of unbound T4.

 

Evaluation of Hypothyroidism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Incorrect because subclinical hypothyroidism would show an elevated TSH but normal free T4 levels.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect as hyperthyroidism would typically present with low TSH and high free T4 levels.

 

Option C. Secondary hypothyroidism: Incorrect for this scenario because secondary hypothyroidism involves a problem with pituitary TSH production, which does not typically result in a significantly elevated TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH and low free T4 levels, indicating a failure of the thyroid gland itself to produce sufficient hormones.

questions.text: In a Pulmonary Function Test at what volume or capacity does the pressure measured at the upper airway reach zero?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

  • The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. It is measured by a spirometer.
  • FRC → ERV + RV
  • At the lung volume corresponding to functional residual capacity (FRC), the lungs are in a relaxed state, and the pressure inside them becomes virtually negligible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation, but it does not correspond to the point where airway pressure is zero.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: Incorrect. Total lung capacity is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold, which includes all lung volumes, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Incorrect. Inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal expiration, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity is the lung volume at which the pressure in the upper airway reaches zero, indicating a relaxed state of the lungs.

choices.text: Contraction stress test

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contraction stress test

 

The fetal biophysical profile (BPP) is a comprehensive assessment used to evaluate fetal well-being, and it includes five components:

 

  1. NST (Non-Stress Test): Evaluates fetal heart rate reactivity.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): Assessed through ultrasound to check the amount of amniotic fluid.
  3. Fetal Movement: Observes fetal movements through ultrasound.
  4. Fetal Tone: Evaluates the presence of fetal muscle tone and limb movements.
  5. Fetal Breathing: Assesses the presence and duration of fetal breathing movements.

 

The Contraction Stress Test (CST) is not part of the BPP. Instead, it is a separate test used to assess the fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions, helping to evaluate how well the fetus handles the stress of contractions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal movement: This is a component of the BPP, assessing the number of fetal movements.

 

Option B. Fetal breathing: This is a component of the BPP, evaluating the presence of fetal breathing movements.

 

Option C. NST: The Non-Stress Test is a key component of the BPP, measuring fetal heart rate reactivity to movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Contraction Stress Test is not a component of the fetal biophysical profile.

 

Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

Explanation:

 

An ulnar nerve damage is suggested by the clinical scenario, which includes a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits.

 

The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle: site C

 

 

Damage to the ulnar nerve at the medial epicondyle causes paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (lack of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion). Hypothenar paralysis (which causes atrophy) and sensory loss are the results. Moreover, the extensor digitorum and flexor digitorum superficialis (provided by the radial nerve and median nerve, respectively) continue to function. The third and fourth digits are therefore not completely paralysed. The palmar interossei's fragility, which causes a loss of adduction, is what causes the positive card test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head of the Humerus: Articulates with the shoulder joint. Injury here typically affects shoulder movement, not the distal functions like finger flexion or sensory issues associated with the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. Intertubercular Groove: Houses the tendon of the biceps brachii. Mainly affects movements related to the biceps muscle, not ulnar nerve functions.

 

Option D. Lateral Epicondyle: Attachment site for forearm extensor muscles. Primarily involved in conditions like lateral epicondylitis, which causes localized pain rather than the broader sensory and motor deficits seen in ulnar nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply:

 

 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

 

Explanation:

 

To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots is not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS): This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:

 

  1. Village Register (Linelisting of cases)
  2. Screening camps
  3. Transport of cases to Base hospital
  4. Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode)
  5. Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

questions.text: Which nerve does the marked structure contain? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV

 

The marked structure in the image is the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which is the thinnest cranial nerve. It is located in the area near the midbrain, passing around the lateral side of the brainstem before entering the cavernous sinus. The trochlear nerve is unique among cranial nerves as it emerges from the dorsal surface of the brainstem (posterior aspect) and is the only cranial nerve that completely decussates before innervating its target structure, the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the thinnest cranial nerve, emerges from the dorsal midbrain, completely decussates, and supplies only the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with regurgitation of food and weight loss over the past several months. A barium swallow is performed. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

The patient presents with symptoms of regurgitation and weight loss, and a barium swallow shows a characteristic "bird's beak" appearance. This finding is highly suggestive of achalasia cardia.

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a functional obstruction of the esophagus. The classic radiographic feature seen on a barium swallow is a smooth, tapered narrowing at the lower esophagus resembling a bird's beak. Symptoms include progressive dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and weight loss.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Esophageal carcinoma: While esophageal carcinoma can present with similar symptoms, it typically occurs in older patients (50yr+) and may produce a similar radiographic appearance, known as "pseudoachalasia." However, the age of the patient and the classic bird's beak appearance make achalasia the more likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Zenker's diverticulum: This condition involves the formation of a diverticulum in the hypopharynx, leading to symptoms such as dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis. The radiographic appearance is different, typically showing a pouch at the back of the throat, rather than the bird's beak seen in achalasia.

 

Option D. Diffuse esophageal spasm: This condition presents with intermittent dysphagia and chest pain. The barium swallow typically shows a corkscrew esophagus due to simultaneous, uncoordinated contractions, which is distinct from the bird's beak appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a bird's beak appearance on a barium swallow. This is the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with regurgitation of food and weight loss.

choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.text: Which of the following statement is True regarding trematodes? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Of the given statements regarding trematodes, the only true statement is that Fasciola hepatica is seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Fasciola hepatica is the largest and most common liver fluke found in man

 

Habitat - The parasite resides in the liver and biliary passages of the definitive host.

 

Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle and man.

 

Intermediate host: Snails

 

Mode of infection: The definitive host, sheep and man, get infection by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

 

Life cycle-

 

 

Unlike other trematodes and basically all other flatworms, the schistosomes are dioecious, i.e., the sexes are separate

 

Schistosoma – Cercariae penetrates through skin, eggs with terminal spine, only snails as intermediate hosts and separate sexes.

 

Praziquantel remains the drug of choice for all trematode infections except fascioliasis, for which triclabendazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma are monoecious: This statement is false. Schistosomes are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes (male and female), which is an exception among trematodes, as most are hermaphroditic.

 

Option C. Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water: This statement is false. Fasciola hepatica infection is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation, not directly through contaminated water.

 

Option D. Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections: This statement is false. While triclabendazole is the drug of choice for fascioliasis, praziquantel remains the drug of choice for most other trematode infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fasciola hepatica is found in the intrahepatic biliary radicles of its definitive host. It is acquired through ingestion of metacercariae on aquatic vegetation, and its treatment of choice is triclabendazole. Schistosomes, unlike other trematodes, are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the Green marked structure in the image in anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

questions.text: During the assessment of the breathing component of a trauma patient, which of the following is the most life-threatening injury that should be identified and managed immediately? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

 

Injuries that significantly impair ventilation in the short term, such as tension pneumothorax, must be identified during the primary survey and treated immediately.

 

It is important to note that the ABCDE protocol of trauma care should be followed, with the primary survey focusing on identifying and managing life-threatening injuries, followed by the secondary survey to identify all other injuries

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, causing it to collapse. This can lead to a rapid buildup of pressure in the chest cavity, compressing the heart and great vessels, which can be life-threatening. It is crucial to identify and manage tension pneumothorax promptly by performing a needle decompression to release the trapped air.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical spine injury: While cervical spine injuries can be serious and require prompt attention, they are not primarily related to the respiratory system. They can result in neurological deficits but are not immediately life-threatening in terms of breathing.

 

Option C. Blunt cardiac injury: Blunt cardiac injury can result from chest trauma and may affect the heart's function. While it can be serious, it may not immediately impact the patient's ability to breathe. However, it requires evaluation and management.

 

Option D. Flail chest: Flail chest is no longer considered an immediate threat to life as per ATLS 2018 guidelines.

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hoover’s sign

 

HOOVER TEST:

 

  • Hoover’s sign is a maneuver to separate organic from non-organic paresis of Leg.
  • Principle: Synergistic Contraction.
  • Involuntary extension of normal leg occurs with flexion of contralateral limb against resistance.
  • Test Positioning:
    • The subject relaxes in a supine position on the table while the examiner places both of the subject’s heels into their palm.
  • Action:
    • The subject is asked to perform a unilateral straight leg raise.
  • Positive Finding:
    • The inability to lift the leg may reflect a neuromuscular weakness.
    • A positive finding is also noted when the examiner does not feel increased pressure in the palm that underlies the resting leg.
    • Organic Cause: Flexion of paralyzed limb → heel of normal limb pushes the examiner’s hand.
    • Functional Weakness: Heel does not pushdown, i.e. the effort is not being transmitted.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waddell’s test. Tests of malingering. Each test counts as +1 if +ve, 0 if –ve. This includes Superficial skin tenderness to light pinch over wide area of lumbar spine; Deep tenderness over wide area, often extending to thoracic spine, sacrum, and/or pelvis; Low back pain on axial loading of spine in standing; SLR test positive in supine, but not when seated with knee extended to test Babinski reflex; Abnormal or inconsistent neurological (motor and/or sensory) patterns; Overreaction. If 3+ points or more are there, investigate for non-organic cause.

 

Option B. O’ Donoghue’s test. Structures affected: Cervical spinal muscles and/or cervical spinal ligaments. The cervical spine of a seated patient is passively flexed, extended, laterally flexed to both sides, and rotated in both directions against patient resistance. Pain precipitated by such isometric contraction indicates cervical strain. The test is then repeated without patient resistance. Pain precipitated by passive unrestricted motion signifies cervical sprain.

 

 

O’Donoghue’s Maneuver for Knee Joint: This maneuver can be used to diagnose meniscal pathologies in the knee. With the patient in prone, the examiner flexes the knee to 90° and then rotates the tibia internally and externally twice, then fully extends the knee and repeat the rotations. Increased pain during rotation in either or both knee positions indicates a meniscal tear or joint capsule irritation. With a valgus force to a flexed and laterally rotated knee, the medial meniscus, medial collateral ligament (MCL), and ACL all may be injured, representing the O'Donoghue triad.

 

Option D. McMurray test. This test indicates tears of the middle or posterior horn of the meniscus. With the patient supine and the hip and knee fully flexed, apply a valgus force and externally rotate the tibia while extending the knee. An audible or palpable pop or snap indicates a medial meniscal tear. Lesions of the lateral meniscus are tested by applying a varus force and internally rotating the tibia during knee extension. The snap is produced as the torn fragment rides over the femoral condyle during extension. A snap in extreme flexion is indicative of a posterior horn tear; a click at 90° of flexion indicates a lesion in the middle section of the meniscus. Only 57% of meniscal root tears result in a positive McMurray test. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as Hoover’s sign.

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Utilizes ribose

 

Explanation:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:

 

Option A. Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells.

 

Option B. Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.

 

Option D. Utilizes ribose: This statement is incorrect as the HMP shunt primarily produces ribose 5-phosphate rather than utilizing it. Ribose 5-phosphate is a significant product of this pathway and is used in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:

 

3G-6-P+6NADP+→2G-6-P+Glyceraldehyde-3-P+3CO2+6NADPH

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HMP shunt is significant for producing NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate and indirectly contributing to the formation of acetyl CoA, but it does not utilize ribose.

questions.text: A patient with AIDS was treated with zidovudine, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole and cotrimoxazole. He developed nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia and insulin resistance. Which of the drugs could have been the cause? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indinavir

 

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It is known for several side effects, which include nephrolithiasis (kidney stones), central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance. These adverse effects are part of the metabolic complications often associated with protease inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that does not typically cause nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, or insulin resistance. Its side effects are more related to hepatotoxicity, adrenal insufficiency, and drug interactions due to CYP3A4 inhibition.

 

Option C. Lamivudine: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It is not commonly associated with nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, or insulin resistance. Its side effects can include lactic acidosis and hepatic steatosis, but these are less common.

 

Option D. Zidovudine: Zidovudine, another NRTI, is associated with side effects such as anemia, neutropenia, and myopathy but not with the specific metabolic complications listed (nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indinavir, a protease inhibitor used in HIV/AIDS treatment, is the drug responsible for causing nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance among the medications listed.

choices.text: Niemann pick disease
Fish eye disease

questions.text: Identify the given image: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gaucher’s disease

 

  • Gaucher's disease is an inherited genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called glucocerebroside in various organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • Symptoms include bone pain, anemia, enlarged organs (hepatosplenomegaly), a swollen and painful belly, easy bruising, and fatigue.
  • Gaucher's disease is most common in Jewish people of Eastern and Central European descent (Ashkenazi).
  • It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, which is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolman's disease:

  • Wolman's disease is a rare autosomal recessive lipid storage disease.
  • It is caused by mutations in the LIPA gene, which encodes lysosomal acid lipase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down lipids.
  • Individuals with Wolman's disease have a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the accumulation of cholesterol and triglycerides in various organs, including the liver, spleen, and intestines.
  • Symptoms often appear in infancy and may include enlarged liver and spleen, abdominal distension, diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

 

Option C. Niemann-Pick disease:

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a rare inherited disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize fat (cholesterol and lipids) within cells.
  • There are several subtypes of Niemann-Pick disease, including types A, B, and C, each caused by different genetic mutations.
  • Symptoms can vary depending on the subtype but may include hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), neurological problems, and respiratory difficulties.
  • Type C Niemann-Pick disease, in particular, can lead to cognitive and motor impairment.

 

Option D. Fish eye disease:

  • Fish eye disease is a rare genetic disorder and is a variant of familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) deficiency.
  • It is characterized by a deficiency of the LCAT enzyme, which plays a role in cholesterol metabolism.
  • Fish eye disease leads to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and can cause eye problems, including corneal opacities and vision impairment.
  • Unlike the more severe form of LCAT deficiency, known as LCAT deficiency, Fish eye disease typically has milder symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows crumpled tissue paper appearance of macrophage cells (see images below) which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. This disease is a type of sphingolipidoses and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme β-glucosyl ceramidase.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

  • Hess chart is a diagnostic tool used to assess the field of a binocular single vision.
  • It is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus.
  • Incomitant strabismus is a type of squint that occurs due to the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies.
  • The chart consists of a smaller chart that indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart that indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.
  • The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

 

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

 

 

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

 

 

Option D: The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

choices.text: Third part of duodenum is compressed
Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about superior mesenteric artery syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

 

In superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, the aortomesenteric angle is reduced to less than 25 degrees, which normally is between 38-65 degrees.

 

This statement is incorrect. In SMAS, the angle between the SMA and aorta is typically less than 20 to 25 degrees, not more than 70 degrees. The narrowing of this angle contributes to the compression of the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Third part of duodenum is compressed: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome involves the compression of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA and the aorta.

 

Option C. Surgical management is by Duodenojejunostomy: This statement is correct. One of the surgical treatments for SMAS is Duodenojejunostomy, which involves creating an opening between the duodenum and the jejunum to bypass the compressed area.

 

Option D. Also known as Wilkie's Syndrome: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome is also known as Wilkie's Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMA syndrome, also called Wilkie's syndrome, is characterized by an obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA due to compression against fixed retroperitoneal structures. Symptoms include episodic epigastric pain associated with vomiting.

 

 

 

SMA syndrome is associated with:

 

  • Rapid growth during childhood
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the GIT
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta

 

Abdominal CT angiography is the investigation of choice.

 

Treatment involves measures to promote weight gain like NJ feeds, which will lead to widening to aortomesenteric angle (due to deposition of fat). If it fails, then a duodeno-jejunal bypass is done.

questions.text:
Mrs. Smith has been referred to the plastic surgery department for the reconstruction of a large wound on her thigh. After a thorough examination, the surgeon decides to perform a skin graft. While discussing the procedure with Mrs. Smith, the surgeon explains the difference between split skin and full-thickness skin grafts. Identify the true statement regarding split thickness and full-thickness skin grafts:(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Primary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  2. Secondary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  3. Primary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
  4. Secondary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Split skin grafts are partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a part of the dermis, while full-thickness grafts consist of the epidermis along with the entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Primary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to passive recoil of the elastin fibers of the dermis in full thickness grafts. Since full-thickness grafts have more dermis (implying more elastin fibers), they undergo more primary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Secondary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to the pull of myofibroblasts, and it occurs over time, when the transplanted graft starts healing. Full-thickness grafts have more ability to resist the pull of myofibroblasts, hence they have less secondary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Primary contracture: FTSG

 

Secondary contracture: STSG

 

Thus, statements 2 and 3 are correct.

choices.text: IgM is the most common antibody in ABO
ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth
ABO antigens are carbohydrates
Antibodies are present only if antigens are absent

questions.text: Regarding ABO blood grouping, which statement is false? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth

 

The statement "ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth" is false. While ABO antibodies are indeed considered natural antibodies, they are not present at birth. These antibodies develop through a process called molecular mimicry after exposure to gut commensals. Typically, ABO antibodies begin to appear around 3 to 6 months of age, not immediately after birth as the statement suggests.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. IgM is the most common antibody in ABO: This statement is correct. IgM is the predominant antibody type in the ABO blood group system. This characteristic is important because IgM antibodies, due to their large size, cannot cross the placenta, which is crucial for preventing complications during pregnancy.

 

Option C. ABO antigens are carbohydrates:  This statement is correct. ABO antigens are oligosaccharides, which are carbohydrate structures. This fact has been established and discussed multiple times in the context of blood group antigens.

 

Option D. Antibodies are present only if antigens are absent: This statement is also correct. In the ABO blood group system, an individual's blood will contain antibodies against the ABO antigens that are not present on their own red blood cells. This principle is fundamental to understanding ABO blood group compatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABO antibodies, while natural, are not present at birth but develop in the first few months of life (typically 3-6 months) through exposure to environmental factors, particularly gut bacteria.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor
  2. Take the sample
  3. Make smear on a slide
  4. Fix the smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence for the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing is as follows:

 

Procedure of taking a pap smear:

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor: The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco's speculum is introduced to visualize the cervix.
  2. Take the sample: The ectocervix is scraped with Ayre's spatula, and the endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush.
  3. Make smear on a slide: The samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides.
  4. Fix the smear: The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol (either immersed or sprayed). After immersion in fixative for 30 minutes, the slide is removed and air dried.

 

Additional Steps:

 

  • Staining: The fixed slide is stained with Papanicolaou stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for collecting samples for a pap smear is to first use a posterior vaginal wall retractor to visualize the cervix, take the sample, make the smear on a slide, and then fix the smear using 95% ethyl alcohol.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obligate intracellular organism

 

Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e, it is a facultative intracellular organism.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is an obligate human pathogen and is the etiological agent of gonorrhea.

 

Habitat –

 

  • Human is only the natural host.
  • Found in human urogenital tract.
  • Rectal carriage in healthy individuals.
  • Typically seen in pus cells (intracellular)
  • Found intracellularly in polymorphonuclear leukocytes, or a specific category of white blood cells with varying shapes of nuclei.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Catalase and oxidase positive: This is true for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which tests positive for both catalase and oxidase enzymes.

 

Option B. Pili is a virulence factor: Neisseria gonorrhoeae has pili on its surface, which are essential for its virulence, aiding in attachment and colonization.

 

Option D. Shows twitching motility: Neisseria gonorrhoeae exhibits twitching motility, a type of bacterial movement.

 

Educational Objective

 

Morphology of Neisseria Gonorrhea -

 

  • Gram –ve cocci
  • Shape is spherical
  • Coffee bean shaped diplococcic
  • Usually seen in pairs with adjacent sides flattened
  • LPS has highly branched basal oligosaccharide structure
  • Contains fimbriae
  • Possess pili on the surface
  • Motile (Twitching motility)
  • Non-capsulated
  • Non-sporing

 

It is catalase and oxidase positive.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cataract

 

  • Cataract is not a common ocular manifestation of dengue infection.
  • Dengue infection can have various manifestations in different organ systems, primarily characterized by inflammation and bleeding.
  • Until recently, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection, apart from retro-orbital pain.
  • The potential pathogenic mechanisms for dengue-related eye involvement may include direct viral effects on the eye, immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Common in dengue due to increased fragility of blood vessels and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Uveitis: While less common, uveitis can occur in dengue fever as part of a systemic immune response to the infection.

 

Option D. Retinal hemorrhage: This is a direct consequence of the hemorrhagic tendency in dengue fever, related to thrombocytopenia and vascular fragility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

 

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis.
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.text: Best method of diagnosis for Clostridium difficile? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxin gene detection by PCR

 

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PC assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool have been approved for diagnostic purposes of Clostridium difficile infection due to high sensitivity, specificity and rapid turnaround time.

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

 

  1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus
  2. Toxin A or B detected in the stool, toxin- producing C. difficile detected in the stool by PCR or ELISA, or pseudo membranes seen in the colon.

 

Other diagnostic methods include:

 

  • Stool Culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating Toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by Enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonscopy or sigmoidoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure strain isolation from culture: Stool culture on selective media can identify C. difficile. However, it is not the best method due to longer turnaround times and the need for specialized techniques. It is highly sensitive but less practical for rapid diagnosis. Also the mere presence of clostridium difficile does not suggest infection with the organism unless toxin production is checked.

 

Option B. Immunofluorescence:

Immunofluorescence can be used for detecting C. difficile antigens. It is less commonly used due to the complexity of the procedure and lower sensitivity compared to PCR.

 

Option D. Toxin Detection by ELISA: ELISA can detect toxins in stool samples. Although it is a useful method, it is less sensitive and specific compared to PCR, making it a secondary choice for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for diagnosing Clostridium difficile infection is through nucleic acid amplification tests, such as PCR assays, which detect the toxin A or B genes in stool due to their high sensitivity, specificity, and rapid turnaround time.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. Her vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. Which of the following is used as first-line management to treat the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The patient's ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia. This type of tachycardia, in a stable patient, is initially managed with vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage or the Valsalva maneuver. These maneuvers aim to increase parasympathetic tone and slow conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node. If vagal maneuvers are ineffective or not feasible, the next step is to administer an AV nodal blocker.

 

Adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment for stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia. It works by transiently blocking the AV node, thereby interrupting the re-entrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia. The initial dose of adenosine is 6 mg administered rapidly IV push, followed by a 10 ml saline flush. If the tachycardia persists, additional doses of 12 mg may be given, with a maximum cumulative dose of 30 mg. Adenosine has a very short half-life of approximately 8 to 10 seconds, necessitating rapid (IV push) administration and immediate follow-up with normal saline to ensure efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is used for the treatment of various types of arrhythmias, including wide complex tachycardias (regular and monomorphic rhythm).

 

Option B. DC Cardioversion: Direct current (DC) cardioversion is used in cases of hemodynamic instability or when pharmacological treatment fails. It is not the first-line treatment for a stable patient presenting with regular narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can be used to manage atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm, because in that case adenosine is contraindicated).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia, adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below. The given FFA is characteristic of which of the following? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macular ischemia

 

  • The FFA image shows features suggestive of macular ischemia (see the images below).
  • The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyper fluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in the disc region and elsewhere.

 

 

  • The FFA is showing enlarged fovea avascular zone arrow (white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow).
  • Both of which are suggestive of macular ischemia which when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards diabetic macular ischemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macular edema: shows the characteristic petaloid appearance.

 

Option C. Submacular/subretinal hemorrhage: obscure the choroidal dye visualization in the corresponding area, appearing similar to capillary non-perfusion but spreads across vascular zones without a defined pattern. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however, be visualized.

 

Option D. Premacular hemorrhage/ vitreous hemorrhage: obscure the visualization of even retinal vasculature and would appear as a region of hypo fluorescence with no retinal vasculature visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macular ischemia in diabetic patients can be identified in FFA images by an enlarged foveal avascular zone and visible areas of capillary non-perfusion, key indicators of decreased vascular supply to the macula.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions, as depicted in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

 

  • The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome which is associated with severe pain; hence the most likely diagnosis here would be herpes zoster or shingles.
  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: This is a viral infection of the skin that causes small, pearly, or flesh-coloured bumps. The lesions are typically umbilicated, meaning they have a small indentation or dimple at the centre as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Option D. Lymphangioma circumscriptum: This condition presents as vesicles filled with lymphatic fluid as shown in the image below. It typically does not have the painful, dermatomal distribution seen in herpes zoster.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ability to recognize Herpes Zoster by its characteristic painful, vesicular rash in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28, 109.36, 128.2,

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the CT scan? (INCET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior ethmoidal canal  

 

Explanation:

 

Anterior ethmoidal canal is noted by the marked arrows. The anterior ethmoidal canal can be recognized by the fact that it lies below the ethmoidal air cell roof. To prevent bleeding from this vessel during sinus procedures, it is crucial to recognize that the anterior ethmoidal artery runs via this canal. Maxillary sinus is noted in this view hence suggesting anterior plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The posterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve pass via the ethmoid bone’s posterior ethmoid canal or foramen. Due to the fact that this image is a coronal section taken at the level of the anterior ethmoidal cells, it cannot be seen.

 

Option C. The optic nerve can be identified as an oval intraorbital structure in the coronal sections.

 

Option D. The cribriform plate is a sieve-like structure between the nasal cavity and the anterior cranial fossa. It is part of the ethmoid bone and as it is pierced by the olfactory nerve fibers. Crista Galli is also a part of ethmoid bone that projects superiorly from the cribriform plate. It provides attachment for the falx cerebri.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal canal is critical to identify during sinus procedures to avoid complications such as bleeding from the anterior ethmoidal artery. It is located below the roof of the ethmoidal air cells and anterior to the posterior ethmoidal canal.

questions.text: A 15-day-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest X-ray examination revealed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/ML (N 43, L 54, and E3). Which of the following is the most likely pathogenic organism? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

The most likely organism causing the infections described in this case is Chlamydia trachomatis. Infants born to women with active, untreated chlamydial infections are at risk of acquiring C. trachomatis, which can lead to neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia. The latter is characterized by an insidious onset of symptoms, generally appearing between 1 and 3 months of age.

 

Key clinical features of C. trachomatis pneumonia include a persistent cough, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and the absence of fever, which are typical in affected infants. On auscultation, rales (abnormal breath sounds) are commonly noted, but wheezing is rare, helping to distinguish this type of pneumonia from other respiratory infections such as those caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

 

Laboratory findings often include peripheral eosinophilia (eosinophil count >400 cells/µL), which is a distinctive marker of C. trachomatis pneumonia in infancy. Chest radiographs commonly show hyperinflation of the lungs with minimal interstitial or alveolar infiltrates, which are consistent findings in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: While Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of pneumonia in children, it is less likely in this case because the onset is typically more acute and associated with high fever. Moreover, this bacterium does not usually cause conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: This pathogen can cause neonatal conjunctivitis, but it is less likely to cause pneumonia. Moreover, Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes a more severe conjunctivitis within the first few days of life, not at 15 days of age.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia in older children and young adults, but it is very uncommon in infants. It also does not typically present with the characteristic features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chlamydia trachomatis can cause neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia, typically presenting with an insidious onset of cough, tachypnea, absence of fever, and peripheral eosinophilia in infants aged 1 to 3 months.

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankle

 

HAGLUND DEFORMITY

 

  • Haglund deformity is prominent Calcaneal tuberosity and overlying bursitis (retro-calcaneal).
  • It is a bony enlargement formed at posterosuperior aspect of calcaneum along with retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marcus Gunn pupil  

 

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage.
  • A defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye can cause a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test.
  • The Marcus Gunn pupil is observed when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye and the affected pupil dilates instead of remaining constricted.
  • Seen in optic neuritis.
  • Earliest indictor of optic nerve disease (Retrobulbar neuritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adie tonic pupil is a Sluggishly reacting mid-dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

 

Option C. Argyll-Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation, which is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus.

 

Option D. Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marcus Gunn pupil, or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage, and is identified using the swinging flashlight test.

choices.text: 1 & 3; a, c, d
2 & 4; b, c, e
1 & 3; a, d
2 & 4; b, e

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

Clinical findings

 

a. Pulsus bisferiens

b. Pulsus alternans

c. Ejection systolic murmur

d. Murmur increases on standing

e. Murmur decreases on standing

 

Management

 

1. Beta-blockers are given

2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated

3. ICD is indicated

4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

The echocardiography findings and symptoms are indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, due to the thickening of the heart muscle, there is a dynamic obstruction to blood flow, often worsening with decreased preload, such as when standing.

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a) is commonly observed in conditions like HCM, where there are two distinct peaks in arterial pulse per cardiac cycle due to the dynamic obstruction.
  • Ejection systolic murmur (c) is typical in HCM and is due to the obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Murmur increases on standing (d) in HCM due to increased obstruction with reduced venous return.

 

Regarding management:

 

  • Beta-blockers (1) are typically used in HCM to manage symptoms and reduce heart rate, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and the degree of obstruction.
  • ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) (3) is recommended in patients with HCM who are at high risk of sudden cardiac death.

ICD indicated for all patients with ≥1 risk factor for SCD or HCM-AF score >6%

 

MAVACAMTEN is recently approved drug which modulates b-myosin heavy chain (↓Bridging & Inotropy) & reduces the need for ablation by 80% in long term

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This is incorrect as it suggests that beta-blockers are contraindicated and includes "murmur decreases on standing," which is not characteristic of HCM. Pulsus alternans (b), indicative of severe heart failure, is not typical in HCM without heart failure.

 

Option C. It misses the key management and diagnostic features by excluding the ejection systolic murmur, which is a significant finding in HCM.

 

Option D. This incorrectly includes beta-blockers as contraindicated and excludes the key symptom of an ejection systolic murmur. It also incorrectly suggests that ICD is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  • All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

 

Option B. Globin part of hemoglobin: 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Globin part of myoglobin: 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin. Myoglobin, primarily found in muscle tissue, has a higher affinity for oxygen and does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. Heme part of myoglobin: The heme part of myoglobin binds to oxygen directly; 2,3-BPG does not bind to this site or affect myoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option D. Heme part of hemoglobin: While the heme part of hemoglobin is the site for oxygen binding, 2,3-BPG does not bind here. It binds at a separate site on the globin chains to modulate oxygen affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female came for treatment of infertility to OPD, Bromocriptine was prescribed. What could be the possible reason? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
